concepts.name: Actigraphic Sleep
concepts.description: Objective measurement of sleep-wake patterns using wearable actigraphy devices that record movement as a proxy for activity and rest. In this study, it provided continuous, non-invasive data on sleep efficiency, duration, and timing in older adults.

concepts.name: Circadian Rest/Activity Rhythms
concepts.description: Endogenous biological rhythms that regulate daily cycles of activity and rest, synchronized with the light-dark cycle. The study assessed their integrity in early Alzheimer’s disease using actigraphy-derived metrics.

concepts.name: Light-Dependent Phase Delay
concepts.description: A shift in the timing of circadian rhythms toward later hours, often observed in neurodegenerative conditions. MCI patients showed phase delay, suggesting disrupted synchronization with environmental cues.

concepts.name: Sleep Efficiency (SE)
concepts.description: The ratio of total sleep time to time in bed, reflecting sleep quality. Lower SE in MCI patients indicates fragmented or poor-quality sleep, a key early marker of neurodegeneration.

concepts.name: Relative Amplitude (RA)
concepts.description: A non-parametric measure of circadian rhythm strength, calculated as the difference between average daytime and nighttime activity divided by their sum. Reduced RA in MCI reflects weakened circadian output.

concepts.name: fPC3 (Functional Principal Component 3)
concepts.description: A novel functional principal component derived from actigraphy data that captures reduced nighttime and morning activity, low amplitude, and phase delay. It emerged as a sensitive discriminator between MCI and cognitively normal individuals.

concepts.name: Functional Principal Component Analysis
concepts.description: A statistical technique that decomposes time-series activity data into orthogonal components explaining variance in rhythmic patterns. Used here to extract fPC1–fPC3 from actigraphy signals.

concepts.name: Daytime Activity Patterns
concepts.description: The distribution and intensity of physical activity during waking hours, which can reflect cognitive and motor function. Altered patterns in MCI suggest early neurobehavioral disruption.

concepts.name: Cognitive Normality
concepts.description: The absence of measurable cognitive impairment as defined by standardized neuropsychological testing. Served as the control group in this study for comparison with MCI.

concepts.name: Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI)
concepts.description: A transitional stage between normal aging and dementia, characterized by subtle but measurable cognitive decline. The study focused on MCI as a marker of early Alzheimer’s disease.

concepts.name: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) Early Phase
concepts.description: The pre-dementia stage of Alzheimer’s disease where pathological changes are underway but clinical symptoms are mild. This study targeted this phase to identify early biomarkers.

concepts.name: fPC1 (Functional Principal Component 1)
concepts.description: A functional component representing high daytime activity and strong circadian amplitude. Lower fPC1 scores were associated with better executive function, indicating its role in activity pattern integrity.

concepts.name: fPC2 (Functional Principal Component 2)
concepts.description: A derived component capturing intermediate rhythmic features not fully explained by fPC1 or fPC3. Its role was less prominent but contributed to overall variance explanation.

concepts.name: WASO (Wake After Sleep Onset)
concepts.description: The total time spent awake after initially falling asleep, used as a measure of sleep continuity. Lower WASO in MCI was linked to better executive function.

concepts.name: IV (Intra-daily Variability)
concepts.description: A measure of fragmentation in activity patterns, reflecting how frequently activity levels change throughout the day. Lower IV was associated with better cognitive performance.

concepts.name: IS (Inter-daily Stability)
concepts.description: A metric quantifying the consistency of daily activity patterns across days. Higher IS indicates stable circadian rhythms, which correlated with better memory and executive function.

concepts.name: Daytime Activity Peak
concepts.description: The highest level of activity during the day, typically occurring in the morning or midday. Reduced peak activity in MCI reflects circadian disruption and neurodegeneration.

concepts.name: Nighttime Activity Suppression
concepts.description: The normal reduction in activity during sleep hours. Impaired suppression in MCI indicates poor sleep consolidation and circadian dysregulation.

concepts.name: Circadian Amplitude Reduction
concepts.description: A decline in the difference between peak daytime and trough nighttime activity, indicating weakened circadian output. A core finding in MCI patients.

concepts.name: Neurobehavioral Biomarker
concepts.description: A measurable biological indicator of neurological or behavioral changes. The study proposes circadian metrics as potential non-invasive biomarkers for early AD.

concepts.name: Non-Invasive Monitoring
concepts.description: The use of wearable devices like actigraphy to collect physiological data without requiring invasive procedures. Key to the study’s translational potential.

concepts.name: Cognitive Function Composite Scores
concepts.description: Derived metrics combining multiple neuropsychological tests into single indices. Used here to create factor-based scores for episodic memory and executive function.

concepts.name: Factor Analysis
concepts.description: A statistical method used to identify underlying latent variables from multiple cognitive test scores. Applied to derive composite memory and executive function scores.

concepts.name: Multivariate Regression
concepts.description: A statistical model adjusting for multiple covariates (age, sex, education, APOE-4) to assess independent associations between circadian metrics and cognition.

concepts.name: APOE-4 Gene Variant
concepts.description: A major genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease. The study adjusted for this variable to isolate the effect of circadian rhythms on cognition.

concepts.name: Causal Inference Limitation
concepts.description: The inability of cross-sectional designs to determine whether circadian disruption precedes or follows cognitive decline. A key limitation acknowledged in the paper.

concepts.name: Temporal Dynamics of Disease
concepts.description: The progression of pathological changes over time. The study’s cross-sectional nature limits understanding of how circadian rhythms evolve during early AD.

concepts.name: Clinical Translation Potential
concepts.description: The feasibility of applying research findings to real-world clinical settings. The study highlights actigraphy’s potential for early detection and monitoring.

concepts.name: Light Exposure Influence
concepts.description: Environmental factor that can modulate circadian rhythms. The study notes its absence as a confounder, highlighting a gap in current data.

concepts.name: Medication Confounding
concepts.description: The potential impact of drugs (e.g., sedatives, antidepressants) on sleep and activity patterns. Not accounted for in the analysis, limiting interpretation.

concepts.name: Sleep Architecture Limitation
concepts.description: Actigraphy cannot distinguish between sleep stages (e.g., REM, NREM), limiting insight into deeper sleep physiology. A noted technical constraint.

concepts.name: Statistical Power
concepts.description: The ability to detect true effects given sample size. The small MCI group (n=26) raises concerns about power and generalizability.

concepts.name: Generalizability Concerns
concepts.description: The extent to which findings apply to broader populations. Limited by age, sex, and cohort-specific characteristics of the BIOCARD sample.

concepts.name: Biological Plausibility
concepts.description: The theoretical support for circadian disruption as a mechanism in neurodegeneration, based on known roles of the suprachiasmatic nucleus and melatonin.

concepts.name: Neurodegenerative Pathophysiology
concepts.description: The underlying biological processes of brain degeneration in Alzheimer’s disease. Circadian disruption is proposed as an early manifestation of this process.

concepts.name: Early Diagnostic Biomarker
concepts.description: A measurable indicator detectable before clinical symptoms appear. The study positions circadian metrics as promising candidates for early AD detection.

concepts.name: Non-Parametric Rhythm Metrics
concepts.description: Circadian measures that do not assume a specific waveform (e.g., RA, IS, IV). Used in this study to avoid model bias in rhythm analysis.

concepts.name: Variance Explained by fPCs
concepts.description: The proportion of total rhythmic variation captured by the first three functional principal components. fPC1–fPC3 together explained 69% of the data variance.

concepts.name: Activity Pattern Fragmentation
concepts.description: Disruption in the continuity of daily activity, reflected in high IV and low IS. Associated with cognitive decline in MCI.

concepts.name: Circadian Phase Delay
concepts.description: A shift in the timing of peak activity to later in the day, observed in MCI patients. Indicates misalignment with environmental light cues.

methods.name: Actigraphy Monitoring
methods.description: Continuous recording of movement using wearable accelerometers to infer sleep-wake cycles and activity patterns. Used to collect objective, long-term data on rest/activity rhythms.

methods.name: Functional Principal Component Analysis
methods.description: A computational method applied to time-series actigraphy data to extract orthogonal components (fPC1–fPC3) that capture dominant patterns of variation in circadian activity.

methods.name: Factor Analysis
methods.description: A statistical technique used to reduce multiple cognitive test scores into two composite variables: episodic memory and executive function, based on shared variance.

methods.name: Multivariate Regression
methods.description: A statistical model that simultaneously evaluates the association between multiple circadian metrics and cognitive scores while adjusting for confounders (age, sex, education, APOE-4).

methods.name: Cross-Sectional Design
methods.description: A study design that collects data at a single time point to compare groups (MCI vs. controls). Used here to assess associations but not causality.

methods.name: Non-Parametric Rhythm Metrics
methods.description: Calculation of circadian indices (RA, IV, IS) without assuming a specific waveform, providing robust measures of rhythm strength and stability.

methods.name: Cognitive Composite Scoring
methods.description: A method to combine individual neuropsychological test results into single, interpretable scores using factor analysis, enabling group-level cognitive assessment.

methods.name: BIOCARD Cohort Data
methods.description: Use of longitudinal, well-characterized data from the Biomarkers for Alzheimer’s Disease (BIOCARD) study, providing standardized clinical and biological measures.

methods.name: Sleep Parameter Extraction
methods.description: Automated computation of standard sleep metrics (TST, SE, WASO, WBL) from actigraphy data using validated algorithms.

methods.name: Adjustment for Covariates
methods.description: Statistical control for potential confounders (age, sex, education, APOE-4) in regression models to isolate the effect of circadian variables on cognition.

methods.name: Variance Decomposition
methods.description: Quantification of how much of the total variation in actigraphy data is explained by the first three fPCs, used to validate the effectiveness of the functional analysis.

methods.name: Group Comparison Analysis
methods.description: Statistical testing (e.g., t-tests or ANCOVAs) to compare mean values of circadian and cognitive variables between MCI and cognitively normal groups.

methods.name: Data Preprocessing
methods.description: Cleaning and normalization of raw actigraphy data, including handling missing values and aligning time series for functional analysis.

methods.name: Time-Series Analysis
methods.description: Application of statistical methods to analyze patterns in longitudinal activity data, forming the basis for functional principal component extraction.

methods.name: Statistical Significance Testing
methods.description: Use of p-values and confidence intervals to determine whether observed differences in group means or associations were likely not due to chance.

methods.name: Covariate Adjustment
methods.description: Inclusion of demographic and genetic variables as covariates in regression models to reduce bias and improve validity of associations.

methods.name: Composite Score Construction
methods.description: Creation of summary cognitive scores by combining factor loadings from multiple tests, enabling multivariate analysis of cognitive performance.

methods.name: Exploratory Data Analysis
methods.description: Initial examination of actigraphy and cognitive data to identify patterns, outliers, and potential relationships before formal modeling.

methods.name: Model Validation
methods.description: Assessment of the robustness of fPCs and regression models through variance explained and sensitivity checks, though not explicitly detailed beyond 69%.

methods.name: Standardized Cognitive Testing
methods.description: Use of validated neuropsychological batteries to assess memory and executive function, ensuring reliability and comparability across participants.
